name: gpsbabel
description: GPSBabel: convert, manipulate, and transfer data from GPS programs or GPS receivers. Open Source and supported on MacOS, Windows, Linux, and more. Pointy clicky GUI or a command line version...
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/gpsbabel/gpsbabel/blob/master/COPYING>.
floss_license_justification: The GPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The GPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: https://www.gpsbabel.org/readme.html
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
release_notes_justification: Non-trivial release notes file in repository: <https://github.com/gpsbabel/gpsbabel/blob/master/NEWS>.
release_notes_vulns_justification: It's not really networked software and has had no CVEs reported in 18 years of existence.
report_process_justification:
Help requests can be placed via mail:
https://www.gpsbabel.org/lists.html
Documented on every page of the web site.
enhancement_responses_justification: Not all requests are accepted but they are at least acknowledged.
build_floss_tools_justification: ./configure && make on most platforms. It uses QT, which is GPL.
test_justification:
All submitted pull requests are automatically run through an automated suite that runs under valgrind, coverity, and other tools to maintain quality.
https://www.gpsbabel.org/quality.html
test_invocation_justification:
./testo runs full regression test.
./vtesto runs the same, but under valgrind which is much slower.
test_policy_justification:
New code is required to have test suite that is covered on all submits.
https://github.com/gpsbabel/gpsbabel/blob/master/format_skeleton.cc
tests_documented_added_justification: Test requirement documented in step 6 of https://github.com/gpsbabel/gpsbabel/blob/master/format_skeleton.cc
warnings_justification:
https://www.gpsbabel.org/quality.html
Builds with -Wall on all compilers, clang-tidy run regularly.
warnings_fixed_justification:
Our primary builds (MacOS, Windows, CentOS) build without warnings at release.
New OSes, especially those that add new warnings under -Wall, may aadd hyperactive warnings that the primary developers don't encounter. That's the reality of cross-platform code that builds on a wide variety of environments.
warnings_strict_justification: Our primary builds (MacOS, Windows, CentOS) build with Wall and without warnings at release.
delivery_unsigned_justification: GPSBabel does not deal in cryptography itself.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: We've steadily marched the issue count toward zero, down from several hundred. We have a few dozen left that have been analyzed and are of minor consequences.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: We use valgrind, memory-sanitizer on combination of all the inupts and all the outputs on every patch submitted (via "testo" and "vtesto" being run on presubmit)
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: We make extensive use of c assert, C14 assert, and internal macros that wrap predicate check to calls that terminate the program (which will fail presubmit) and prevent an unsafe runtime.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: Every leak, overwrite, etc. is fixed before submit.
general_comments: GPSBabel has been the leading program for GPS data interchange and manipulation since 2001. It is used by many other program like Google Earth, many geotaggers", the the Geocaching Swiss Army Knife for many of its key features like "caching along a route", "finding caches in a state" and all it's GPSBrorotocols.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
implementation_languages: C++, C, Shell, Makefile, Batchfile, M4, Perl, QMake, CMake, XSLT, Inno Setup, Tcl, Dockerfile, JavaScript

name: Hyperledger Aries
description: Hyperledger Aries is infrastructure for blockchain-rooted, peer-to-peer interactions as defined in the Trust over IP Technical Stack, Layers 2 (secure peer to peer communications) and 3 (data exchange protocols). It implements shared, reusable, interoperable tool kits designed for initiatives and solutions focused on creating, transmitting and storing verifiable digital credentials.
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
contribution_requirements_justification: Contributions guidelines are included in most of the Aries repos and definitely in the major ones.  For example:  https://github.com/hyperledger/aries-cloudagent-python/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md and https://github.com/hyperledger/aries-framework-go/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/hyperledger/aries/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification:
The documentation is provided on a per framework basis. For example, the guidance in the ACA-Py repo - https://github.com/hyperledger/aries-cloudagent-python

As well, the Linux Foundation provides the "Becoming an Aries Developer" edX course here: https://www.edx.org/course/becoming-a-hyperledger-aries-developer
documentation_interface_justification:
Both the Aries Framework Go and Aries Cloud Agent Python (at least) provide OpenAPI/Swagger interfaces to support developers using the APIs.  ACA-Py provides this demo for using the API.  https://github.com/hyperledger/aries-cloudagent-python/blob/main/demo/AriesOpenAPIDemo.md

Note that because the API is extensible through a runtime plug-ins capability, the ACA-Py OpenAPI definition is generated on startup, and so is not available as a static instance.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: Tags are used on releases - e.g. https://github.com/hyperledger/aries-cloudagent-python/tags and https://github.com/hyperledger/aries-framework-go/tags
version_tags_justification: Tags are used on releases - e.g. https://github.com/hyperledger/aries-cloudagent-python/tags and https://github.com/hyperledger/aries-framework-go/tags
release_notes_justification: Human created release notes are on tagged final releases - e.g. https://github.com/hyperledger/aries-cloudagent-python/tags and https://github.com/hyperledger/aries-framework-go/tags
release_notes_vulns_justification: To date there have been no CVEs to address and document.  Such documentation will be included whenever it is required in the future.
report_tracker_justification: Project repos use GitHub issues: https://github.com/hyperledger/aries-framework-go/issues and https://github.com/hyperledger/aries-cloudagent-python/issues
report_process_justification:
Project repos use GitHub issues: https://github.com/hyperledger/aries-framework-go/issues and https://github.com/hyperledger/aries-cloudagent-python/issues

Issues are requested via Issues per the Readme: https://github.com/hyperledger/aries-cloudagent-python/blob/main/README.md#contributing
report_responses_justification:
See tracking here: https://github.com/hyperledger/aries-cloudagent-python/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aclosed.  

The team is extremely responsive in responding to issues.
enhancement_responses_justification:
Major requests have been added recently (multi-tenancy, decoupling from indy-sdk, mediator, etc.) and are currently in the works -- e.g. BBS+ credentials, persistent queues, etc.

See also Hyperledger tracking for Aries: 6,w:31,x:0,y:59),id:de3203e0-1ab3-11eb-bbd0-c758192c580e,panelIndex:a476e04a-1dde-4bdc-98b6-8c6d16c30b46,title:Repositories,type:visualization,version:%277.6.2%27),(embeddableConfig:(title:Projects),gridData:(h:19,i:%27077e496f-d414-4840-a3b0-3bc9da32ddcc%27,w:17,x:31,y:59),id:%2770e5e750-1ab5-11eb-b81d-a32b9537df14%27,panelIndex:%27077e496f-d414-4840-a3b0-3bc9da32ddcc%27,title:Projects,type:visualization,version:%277.6.2%27)),query:(language:lucene,query:%27*%27),timeRestore:!f,title:Git,viewMode:view)&time=%7B%22from%22:%22now-6M%22,%22type%22:%22datemath%22,%22to%22:%22now%22%7D
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: None were received in the time period.
build_justification:
CI is implemented per PR submission/update and CD publishes artifacts per tagged release.

Example PR showing CI: https://github.com/hyperledger/aries-cloudagent-python/pull/980
build_common_tools_justification: In the ACA-Py repo, common Python tools are run for analysis and testing. Likewise in the Aries Framework Go repo and common golang tools.
build_floss_tools_justification: The major frameworks in Aries can all be built with only FLOSS tools.
test_justification:
See the Aries Agent Test Harness (https://github.com/hyperledger/aries-agent-test-harness) for interop testing.

Each framework all runs standard test using testing tools appropriate for the tech stack.
test_invocation_justification: Language specific test tools are used in the different framworks.
test_most_justification:
Aries Cloud Agent Python has 98.99% code coverage per codecov for the most recent commit (https://app.codecov.io/gh/hyperledger/aries-cloudagent-python).
Aries Framework Go has 89.14% code coverage per codecov for the most recent commit (https://app.codecov.io/gh/hyperledger/aries-framework-go).
test_policy_justification:
The maintainers are rigorous about ensuring test coverage is included in all new additions to the source base.

Aries Cloud Agent Python has a demo ("Alice and Faber") that is extended with new options for each new major feature added, for both testing purposes and for demonstration for new developers.
tests_are_added_justification: The primary evidence of the completion of this policy is the consistently high code coverage numbers as new features are added.
tests_documented_added_justification: We'll add this, but it is not there now.
warnings_justification: Linter tools are used on the code in the CI pipeline and GitHub's LGTM is actively used in the Aries repos.
warnings_fixed_justification: No PRs are accepted with static analysis warnings or outstanding LGTM complaints.
know_secure_design_justification: Several developers on the ACA-Py and AF-Go teams address those issues in their coding and in their review of code from other contributors.
crypto_published_justification: Any cryptographic dependencies are studied prior to inclusion, coming mainly from Hyperledger Ursa or other well-known suites (e.g. OpenSSL).
crypto_working_justification: None of those algorithms are used.
crypto_pfs_justification: The underlying DIDComm v1 protocol does not implement PFS. This is under consideration in the upcoming transition to DIDComm v2.
static_analysis_justification:
Tools used for Python include -- Black Code formatting/Linting, Code-QL-Build, Code-QL, LGTM
Tools used for Golang include -- LGTM
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: CircleCI is used for CI testing for Aries Cloud Agent Python, GitHub Actions for Aries Framework Go.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
english_justification: The repos of the major frameworks contain extensive documentation in English and accept bug reports and comments about the code using GitHub Issues, GitHub Pull Requests and on Hyperledger Chat.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.

name: Hyperledger Cactus
description: Hyperledger Cactus is a new approach to the blockchain interoperability problem
interact_justification:
GitHub issues templates and a link to open GitHub issues can be found under the wiki:
https://wiki.hyperledger.org/display/cactus
contribution_justification: https://github.com/hyperledger/cactus/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
contribution_requirements_justification:
https://github.com/hyperledger/cactus/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
The CONTRIBUTING.md document discusses (among other things) the automated tools that we have in place for linting code, linting commit messages, pull requests. The auto formatter for code style enforcement and the DCO requirement as well. We also have pull request bots and are planning on adding even more thorough checks via unique GitHub actions.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/hyperledger/cactus/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification:
How to build the project: https://github.com/hyperledger/cactus/blob/master/BUILD.md
Governance: https://github.com/hyperledger/cactus/blob/master/GOVERNANCE.md
Whitepaper draft: https://github.com/hyperledger/cactus/blob/master/whitepaper/whitepaper.md
General documentation folder: https://github.com/hyperledger/cactus/tree/master/docs
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: We use git tags and GitHub releases/milestones to signify past and upcoming releases with GH issues linked to each.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification:
We use semantic versioning where breaking changes can only happen in major release bumps.
https://semver.org/
release_notes_justification:
https://github.com/hyperledger/cactus/releases/tag/v0.1.0
We have automated tooling to generate release notes, but the file will be called CHANGELOG.md. This will appear at the next release only, but we already have the tooling in place.
release_notes_vulns_justification: there have been no publicly known vulnerabilities
report_tracker_justification:
The list of issues can be found here:
https://github.com/hyperledger/cactus/issues

The milestones we have for roadmap planning are here:
https://github.com/hyperledger/cactus/milestones
report_process_justification: Click here to create a new issue based on one of our templates: https://github.com/hyperledger/cactus/issues/new/choose
report_responses_justification: We have an average issue turnaround much lower than the mentioned 2-12 months timeframe.
enhancement_responses_justification: We have resolved the majority of issues opened so far. Project is not yet 12 months old at the time of this writing.
report_archive_justification:
Everything is publicly available on 
1. GitHub: https://github.com/hyperledger/cactus
2. Wiki and mailing list: https://wiki.hyperledger.org/display/cactus
3. Meeting recordings (posted on the wiki)
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: If vulnerability reports are always public (so there are never private vulnerability reports), choose "not applicable" (N/A)
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: If there have been no vulnerabilities reported in the last 6 months, choose "not applicable" (N/A).
build_common_tools_justification: Lerna, Typescript and Webpack are used to build all the packages of the project.
build_floss_tools_justification: All build tools are open source.
test_justification: All tests are open source and part of the git repository. Anyone can run them.
test_invocation_justification: There's an npm script that can run the full build and test suite (the CI script) on any supported operating system.
test_most_justification: Test coverage is about ~50% right now and rapidly improving every week.
test_policy_justification: Pull requests for new features without test coverage will not be accepted by the maintainers.
tests_are_added_justification: The list of pull requests merged in the past will show that tests were required.
warnings_justification: We have TSLint configured for the code: https://github.com/hyperledger/cactus/blob/master/tslint.json
warnings_fixed_justification: We have 100% linter compliance, the build fails without it so no pull requests will be accepted unless they keep this up as well.
warnings_strict_justification: We have 100% linter compliance, the build fails without it so no pull requests will be accepted unless they keep this up as well.
know_secure_design_justification: Among the maintainers there's decades worth of experience. We have people in the community who are research scientists in cryptography/security related fields.
crypto_published_justification: We do not roll our own crypto and not planning on it either. Only use algorithms that were vetted by the math/crypto community.
crypto_call_justification: We do not roll our own crypto and not planning on it either. Only use algorithms that were vetted by the math/crypto community.
crypto_floss_justification: We do not roll our own crypto and not planning on it either. Only use algorithms that were vetted by the math/crypto community.
crypto_keylength_justification: This is covered by our 'secure  by default' design principle which is well documented in the code.
crypto_pfs_justification: We restrict our HTTP APIs to TLS 1.3 and newer by default. (1.2 and older are the ones that have forward secrecy issues AFAIK)
crypto_password_storage_justification: We do not store passwords in the software.
crypto_random_justification: We use NodeJS's crypto module which is believed to be cryptographically secure when it comes to generating random numbers.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: There's an entry specifically about this in our governance document that explains that security related pull requests (fixing vulnerabilities) will be fast tracked.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: We did not have CVSS reported vulnerabilities yet.
static_analysis_often_justification: It happens on every commit and pull requests prior to merging or approving them.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: The project does not produce software written in a memory-unsafe language.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: We use Travis CI to automatically run the full build and test suite on  every branch, commit and PR.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
english_justification: All documentation is written in English, we accept bug reports and comments about code in English as well.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.

name: Artifact Hub
description: Artifact Hub is a web-based application that enables finding, installing, and publishing packages and configurations for CNCF projects.
description_good_justification:
https://artifacthub.io

Artifact Hub is a web-based application that enables finding, installing, and publishing packages and configurations for CNCF projects. For example, this could include Helm charts, Falco configurations, Open Policy Agent (OPA) policies, and OLM operators.

Discovering artifacts to use with CNCF projects can be difficult. If every CNCF project that needs to share artifacts creates its own Hub this creates a fair amount of repeat work for each project and a fractured experience for those trying to find the artifacts to consume. The Artifact Hub attempts to solve that by providing a single experience for consumers that any CNCF project can leverage.

name: victoria
description: Victoria is the SRE toolbelta single command with multiple pluggable subcommands for automating any number of 'toil' tasks that inhibit SRE productivity.

contribution_requirements_justification: Full description of the pull request process and standards is listed here: https://sre.glasswallsolutions.com/victoria/index.html#pull-requests

floss_license_osi_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification:
Some documentation basics file contents found.
Documentation including user guide and developer guide is found here: https://sre.glasswallsolutions.com/victoria/index.html
documentation_interface_justification: API reference can be found here: https://sre.glasswallsolutions.com/victoria/autoapi/index.html
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: Interim versions are released between major versions: https://github.com/glasswall-sre/victoria/releases
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: Semantic versioning is used for release numbers: https://github.com/glasswall-sre/victoria/releases
release_notes_justification: Release notes are found on every release: https://github.com/glasswall-sre/victoria/releases
release_notes_vulns_justification: As of yet there have been no publicly known vulnerabilities.
report_process_justification: GitHub issue tracker is used, with a bug report issue template: https://github.com/glasswall-sre/victoria/issues/new?assignees=&labels=bug&template=bug_report.md&title=%5BBUG%5D+%7BDescription+of+issue%7D
report_responses_justification: No bug reports have yet been submitted, but we do have the capacity to acknowledge all bug reports as they occur.
enhancement_responses_justification: No enhancements have yet been submitted, but we do have the capacity to acknowledge all bug reports as they occur.
report_archive_justification: GitHub is used as an issue tracker and version control system: https://github.com/glasswall-sre/victoria/issues
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: The process for reporting a vulnerability is detailed in the documentation: https://sre.glasswallsolutions.com/victoria/index.html#vulnerability-reports
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: This is detailed in the vulnerability reporting section of the documentation, emails can be sent to a secure email address: https://sre.glasswallsolutions.com/victoria/index.html#vulnerability-reports
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: No vulnerabilities have yet been reported, however in the documentation we agree to acknowledge all reports within one business day: https://sre.glasswallsolutions.com/victoria/index.html#vulnerability-reports
build_justification: Python setuptools is used for this. The project can be built using Twine and the project's setup.py. The project also has CI/CD builds which can be run to build and distribute the software.
build_common_tools_justification: Python setuptools is used for this. The project can be built using Twine and the project's setup.py.
build_floss_tools_justification: Python setuptools is used for this. The project can be built using Twine and the project's setup.py.
test_justification: The project is tested using pytest, with 91% test coverage.
test_invocation_justification: The project can be tested by running pytest in the project root folder, which is standard.
test_policy_justification: Codecov is used to ensure new code added in a PR has a test coverage of at least 80%, also specified in the pull request guide: https://sre.glasswallsolutions.com/victoria/index.html#pull-requests
tests_are_added_justification: Coverage history can be viewed on codecov: https://codecov.io/gh/glasswall-sre/victoria
tests_documented_added_justification: Specified in the pull request guide: https://sre.glasswallsolutions.com/victoria/index.html#pull-requests
warnings_justification: The project uses pylint with warnings enabled. Pull requests are gated by a successful pylint execution.
warnings_fixed_justification: Pull requests are gated by a successful pylint execution.
warnings_strict_justification: The project uses pylint with all warnings enabled.
know_secure_design_justification: I am the primary developer - I have a first class degree in Computer Science, and I have been working as a Software Engineer in the cyber security field for 2 years now.
know_common_errors_justification: I have had experience with addressing/mitigating these kinds of errors in my 2 years experience as a Software Engineer in the cyber security field.
crypto_published_justification:
Victoria uses envelope encryption to encrypt secure data in plugin config files. The key encryption key comes from a secure cloud encryption service (at the moment, only Azure Key Vault is supported), and the data encryption keys are generated according to Google's best practices guide. This means they use a 256-bit AES cipher in Galois Counter Mode, with a 96-bit nonce length (as recommended by NIST for AES in GCM). Keys and nonces are not reused, ever.
This information can be found in the documentation: https://sre.glasswallsolutions.com/victoria/autoapi/victoria/encryption/provider/index.html#victoria.encryption.provider.EncryptionProvider._data_encrypt
crypto_call_justification: Victoria uses cloud encryption providers and the Python cryptography library: https://cryptography.io/en/latest/
crypto_floss_justification: Uses the open-source Python cryptography library: https://github.com/pyca/cryptography
crypto_keylength_justification: Uses a 256-bit AES cipher in Galois Counter Mode, with a 96-bit nonce length (as recommended by NIST for AES in GCM).
crypto_working_justification: Uses a 256-bit AES cipher in Galois Counter Mode, with a 96-bit nonce length (as recommended by NIST for AES in GCM).
crypto_pfs_justification: Uses envelope encryption. Data encryption keys and nonces are never reused, and key encryption keys come from a cloud provider, and key rotation is supported.
crypto_random_justification:
Uses open-source Python cryptography library to generate data encryption keys securely: https://github.com/pyca/cryptography
Generates nonces using Python standard library os.urandom, which is a cryptographically-secure random number generator: https://github.com/glasswall-sre/victoria/blob/master/victoria/encryption/provider.py#L131
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: As of yet there are no vulnerabilities.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: As of yet there are no vulnerabilities.
static_analysis_justification: Pylint is used to check for warnings. SonarCloud is also used: https://sonarcloud.io/dashboard?id=victoria
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: SonarCloud is used to check for vulnerabilities: https://sonarcloud.io/dashboard?id=victoria
static_analysis_often_justification: Static code analysis occurs on pull requests into master. No code can be merged unless static analysis comes back with no issues.
dynamic_analysis_justification: We use Bandit in CI builds to check for vulnerabilties: https://pypi.org/project/bandit/
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: The project does not produce software written in a memory-unsafe language.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: We do not include assertions in our source code. We believe our unit/integration testing combined with static analysis is sufficient to detect errors.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: Uses a 256-bit AES cipher in Galois Counter Mode, with a 96-bit nonce length (as recommended by NIST for AES in GCM).
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: The project has a CI build that tests the code, lints the code, and scans for vulnerabilities. Additionally it uses SonarCloud as a static analysis system. This happens for every pull request.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: The project has not ever leaked any private credentials.
english_justification:
All documentation is written in English: https://sre.glasswallsolutions.com/victoria/index.html
Including the contribution sections: https://sre.glasswallsolutions.com/victoria/index.html#contribution
